critique: This executive order focuses on preventing and combating computer software piracy within the United States government. It directs executive agencies to ensure compliance with copyright laws and international agreements related to intellectual property. It also emphasizes the importance of contractors and recipients of federal financial assistance adhering to these laws. The order establishes responsibilities for agency heads and the Chief Information Officers Council to improve practices regarding the acquisition and use of computer software. It includes provisions to protect national security and law enforcement activities and clarifies that it does not create any new legal rights. It seems to be a fairly centrist document with no strong ideological leaning. It doesn't directly address immigration, executive power, federalism, national security vs. civil liberties, economic regulation, or social inclusion in a significant way. Therefore, most of the scores will be neutral.
